Do you know what the second most spoken sentence in school is? "I'm _REALLY_ tired." As students, we seem to be stuck in a never-ending loop of "wake up, feel tired, go to school, feel more tired, go home, do homework, sleep." At some point, TGIF became TGIFAICSI (Thank god it's Friday and I can sleep in). Heck, it has ingrained itself in my daily vocabulary. The response when people ask me how I am? Either "I'm good" or "I'm tired." Of all the responses my grade 6 french teacher taught for "Comment ça va", that one was not on the list.

In learning React, I've found that it does a lot of things beautifully. With that said, it also does some things not-so-beautifully (mostly due to JavaScript idiosyncrasies more than anything else).

Binding Insanity

Exhibit one:


*Okay, I know inline binding is bad for performance. This is just an example.

I know it's just 10 more characters, but having to put .bind(this in front of every function signature is annoying at best and downright maddening at worst. Fortunately, ES7 has a solution to this:

See? That was easy!

Object.extend all the things

React (and Flux in particular) has this philosophy where data should be immutable for the sake of keeping your application state clear. Historically, shallow copies of your state have been accomplished through Object.extend

Fortunately, one again, there's a far more elegant implementation from ES7 (The Spread Operator):

I know, you're mind has been blown. Now if only there was a similar shorthand for deep copies..

Anyhow, these two shorthands have kept me from going insane while learning and developing apps in React. I'll keep this post updated with any new discoveries I might find.

posts.title: TWIL: React and JavaScript Module Systems
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":" *This is the first post of a new weekly series I'll be embarking on named TWIL (This week I learned). It will cover weekly programming and tech discoveries/mishaps that I encounter.* So I tried to learn React. It went something like this: Okay, I understand the library, but how on planet earth do I include and run it? Do I use [Gulp](http://gulpjs.com)? Dafuq is [webpack](https://webpack.github.io)? What is this CommonJS, AMD, and UMD stuff? And I need to include Babelify? Browserify? Wut??? Needless to say, different sites pointed me to different systems and I just ended up confused. Even Facebook recognizes this with their recent launch of [create-react-app](https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app). So, my friends, here it is - an overview of how the JavaScript build world works. ![Master Diagram](https://static.kevinpei.com/2016/12Untitled_Diagram-1482722779021.png)

Master Build Process Diagram

One of the first mind-blowing things I figured out was that you could `npm install` client-side code (e.g. [Redux](https://github.com/reactjs/redux#installation)). Sure, they get placed in the node\_modules folder, but that's okay. No matter if you're using ES6 or *require*, putting them in node_modules allows you to import them just like how you do in a Node.JS application. ### But how do I include these libs on the client side?? That's where tools like Gulp and Webpack come in. At their very core, Gulp and Webpack don't really do much. Their abilities go something along the lines of *"I can find some files in some directory, do something to them, and then spit them back out somewhere else."* Essentially, a glorified copy-and-paste tool. ### In come the Transpilers, Loaders, and Plugins When I say "transpilers" and "plugins", I mean things like: - Browserify (Find and include modules in builds) - Babelify (Convert newer standards to current JavaScript) - Uglify (Compress and minify files) These are the things that make Gulp and Webpack so powerful. In essence, they act like "powerups" that Gulp and Webpack can make use of. posts.html:
This is the first post of a new weekly series I'll be embarking on named TWIL (This week I learned). It will cover weekly programming and tech discoveries/mishaps that I encounter.

So I tried to learn React. It went something like this: Okay, I understand the library, but how on planet earth do I include and run it? Do I use Gulp? Dafuq is webpack? What is this CommonJS, AMD, and UMD stuff? And I need to include Babelify? Browserify? Wut???

Needless to say, different sites pointed me to different systems and I just ended up confused. Even Facebook recognizes this with their recent launch of create-react-app. So, my friends, here it is - an overview of how the JavaScript build world works.

Master Build Process Diagram

One of the first mind-blowing things I figured out was that you could npm install client-side code (e.g. Redux). Sure, they get placed in the node_modules folder, but that's okay. No matter if you're using ES6 or require, putting them in node_modules allows you to import them just like how you do in a Node.JS application.

But how do I include these libs on the client side??

That's where tools like Gulp and Webpack come in. At their very core, Gulp and Webpack don't really do much. Their abilities go something along the lines of "I can find some files in some directory, do something to them, and then spit them back out somewhere else." Essentially, a glorified copy-and-paste tool.

In come the Transpilers, Loaders, and Plugins

When I say "transpilers" and "plugins", I mean things like:

  • Browserify (Find and include modules in builds)
  • Babelify (Convert newer standards to current JavaScript)
  • Uglify (Compress and minify files)

These are the things that make Gulp and Webpack so powerful. In essence, they act like "powerups" that Gulp and Webpack can make use of. For example, you can tell them to "find .js files, use uglify to compress and minify them, and then spit them out as one file in a build directory"

The beauty of Browserify

Remember the problem we had earlier of using stuff from node_modules in the client side? Browserify solves that by scanning your imports and packaging them into your output file in a smart way. In other words, it looks at your source file, plucks all the required modules from node_modules and other places, and puts it all together into a single file such that just works. Pretty cool, eh?

Okay, I can compile JS code now. What's AMD, UMD, and CommonJS?

The problem with JavaScript modules at the moment is that there isn't really much of a standard on how to create and deliver them. There's the AMD specification, CommonJS specification, and ES6 specification to name a few. There's a pretty interesting read on StackOverflow about this. In short, it's basically the war between import MyModule from 'my-module' (ES6), var MyModule = require('my-module') (CommonJS), and other standards. There's a great writeup on how all this came about on Medium.

Introduce UMD

The story goes like this: Some dude on the magical interwebs got tired of all this mismatched horsepoop and made the "Universal Module Definition". Another specification you ask?? No, not really. It's just some special code that makes your module compatible with AMD, CommonJS, and other standards all at the same time.

So which one should I use, and how should I use it?

Use whichever one you want that best fits your needs. I personally recommend UMD simply because it reduces a lot of headache if you need your code in another format sometime in the future.

To actually compile into one of these, just set the appropriate setting or install the appropriate plugin within Gulp/Webpack/Whatever you're using.

How does React play into this?

It happens that React components are a GREAT use of JavaScript modules. After all, Components are essentially just special JavaScript modules. You can use Babel to convert JSX into normal JS through even more plugins (specifically transform-react-jsx). GLHF.

TL;DR. I want the meat of it.

Sorry, this is as simple of an explanation as I can write. I didn't even get into the technical details of using all these things.

But I really, really want a TL;DR

JavaScript is going through its teenage phase of having no idea about what it wants to do. Wrangle with it with all your might, or just go home and cry. Sorry, wish I had a better answer.

posts.title: A Bittersweet Closing
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"It's over... just.. over. I try to summarize these 4 years, but nothing comes to mind. Nada, none, zilch. There's too much to say, too much to reflect upon. I remember the overwhelming energy of SHAD, the torrential insanity of university applications, the never ending stream of stress and relief and despair and happiness that was high school. Like my chemistry exam, there's just too much for me to process. How could I possibly fit 4 years into one measly, little blog post? Looking back, I'm hit by an irony that is too great to not tell. After all this time, I still have no freaking clue what my purpose for going to High School was. Don't get me wrong, it's been great and I've learnt a lot - but was there really any one thing I got from high school that I couldn't have gotten anywhere else? Certainly not the education, what with Khan Academy and the likes making learning anything a simple reality. Heck, there were times when I went to Khan Academy to relearn something I didn't get in class! ![MFW I read my textbook](https://static.kevinpei.com/2016/12DSC_9741-1482722828983.jpg)

MFW I read my textbook

Then, perhaps, it was the resources. But, wait, how many times have I complained about the lackluster experience that is school technology? From never-loading computers to Moodle (a classroom notes and handouts site) going down before major assessments, little positive can be said about the resources that the school provided me with. Well, I guess they did have a rather comprehensive hardware lab. No, it was the people that made high school worth it. I remember the eccentric teachers, supportive guidance department, and incredible friends. It's not the education that makes us rank so high, it's the people. A concentration of talent and passion leads to a concentration of amazing results. Simple as that. To my family, thank you. I know I've been a real hassle these 4 years, and I know I've annoyed you to kingdom come. Yet, despite all this, you continued to support me, to love me, to make me lunches every day despite my pleas for soylent. But there is hope. Mom, I endeavor to learn how to make those delicious sandwiches of yours over the summer. To my friends, thank you. Y'all taught me how to pass chemistry, how to survive fire alarms at 2 in the morning, and, most importantly, how to be social. Seriously, when I began high school I hadn't a clue how to make friends properly. I mean, when you meet someone do you say hi or do you give them a handshake? If so, how hard should you squeeze their hand? What if their hand is oily from KFC? It would not be a joke to say that the hardest class I've had throughout all of high school was "Friendship 101". Every one of you are awesome. To my teachers (who probably aren't reading this), thank you. From demonstrating how to find the volume of a donut to exemplifying why students excel at making parachutes, your influence has not gone unnoticed. Nowhere else have I met such a brilliant group of people who care so much for their students. There really is something special about our school, and it's you teachers that make it so. And, of course, to the one who inspired me, who guided me, who's undeniable spirit shone light upon my darkest days, thank you. Thank you for showing me how to sleep in the snow, how to arch over backwards (sorta), how to wake somebody up with one, single noun. I could not have wished for a better (albeit unwitting) mentor, companion, and ultimate friend. You know who you are. Friends, family, teachers, fellow peers, thank you. I came into high school confused - a bumbling, stumbling duck with no direction nor purpose. It was on this goofy foot that I began my journey, our journey, of inspiring and being inspired. It was you who lent me my great ideas, who showed the way to a better and brighter future. **It is we** who will make this future a reality for generations to come. It is we. I am sure of it. ![](https://static.kevinpei.com/2016/12Untitled_3_1-1482722852947.jpg)



![](https://static.kevinpei.com/2016/12DSC_9734_1-1482722859408.jpg)



"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
It's over... just.. over.

I try to summarize these 4 years, but nothing comes to mind. Nada, none, zilch. There's too much to say, too much to reflect upon. I remember the overwhelming energy of SHAD, the torrential insanity of university applications, the never ending stream of stress and relief and despair and happiness that was high school. Like my chemistry exam, there's just too much for me to process. How could I possibly fit 4 years into one measly, little blog post?

Looking back, I'm hit by an irony that is too great to not tell. After all this time, I still have no freaking clue what my purpose for going to High School was. Don't get me wrong, it's been great and I've learnt a lot - but was there really any one thing I got from high school that I couldn't have gotten anywhere else?

Certainly not the education, what with Khan Academy and the likes making learning anything a simple reality. Heck, there were times when I went to Khan Academy to relearn something I didn't get in class!

MFW I read my textbook

Then, perhaps, it was the resources. But, wait, how many times have I complained about the lackluster experience that is school technology? From never-loading computers to Moodle (a classroom notes and handouts site) going down before major assessments, little positive can be said about the resources that the school provided me with. Well, I guess they did have a rather comprehensive hardware lab.

No, it was the people that made high school worth it. I remember the eccentric teachers, supportive guidance department, and incredible friends. It's not the education that makes us rank so high, it's the people. A concentration of talent and passion leads to a concentration of amazing results. Simple as that.

To my family, thank you. I know I've been a real hassle these 4 years, and I know I've annoyed you to kingdom come. Yet, despite all this, you continued to support me, to love me, to make me lunches every day despite my pleas for soylent. But there is hope. Mom, I endeavor to learn how to make those delicious sandwiches of yours over the summer.

To my friends, thank you. Y'all taught me how to pass chemistry, how to survive fire alarms at 2 in the morning, and, most importantly, how to be social. Seriously, when I began high school I hadn't a clue how to make friends properly. I mean, when you meet someone do you say hi or do you give them a handshake? If so, how hard should you squeeze their hand? What if their hand is oily from KFC? It would not be a joke to say that the hardest class I've had throughout all of high school was "Friendship 101". Every one of you are awesome.

To my teachers (who probably aren't reading this), thank you. From demonstrating how to find the volume of a donut to exemplifying why students excel at making parachutes, your influence has not gone unnoticed. Nowhere else have I met such a brilliant group of people who care so much for their students. There really is something special about our school, and it's you teachers that make it so.

And, of course, to the one who inspired me, who guided me, who's undeniable spirit shone light upon my darkest days, thank you. Thank you for showing me how to sleep in the snow, how to arch over backwards (sorta), how to wake somebody up with one, single noun. I could not have wished for a better (albeit unwitting) mentor, companion, and ultimate friend. You know who you are.

Friends, family, teachers, fellow peers, thank you. I came into high school confused - a bumbling, stumbling duck with no direction nor purpose. It was on this goofy foot that I began my journey, our journey, of inspiring and being inspired. It was you who lent me my great ideas, who showed the way to a better and brighter future. It is we who will make this future a reality for generations to come.

It is we. I am sure of it.

posts.title: Why Donald Trump might just be a blessing in disguise
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Brandon Stanton, founder of Humans of New York, wrote an interesting piece titled "[An Open Letter to Donald Trump](https://www.facebook.com/humansofnewyork/posts/1207382856002479)" on his organization's Facebook page today. In short, he makes the claim that Trump's bigoted, unabashed manner has transcended the line from a political issue to a moral issue. Indeed, never before have I heard anybody, let alone a political figure, say that they "[they] could shoot somebody and not lose any voters." Attribute that and his other statements to simple, pure hyperbole if you will, but there is no denying that Donald Trump has built up a strong, loyal following and, at this point, appears to be the inevitable GOP candidate for the presidency. 

As a Canadian citizen, I try not to judge American politics too harshly. With that said, it would be an understatement to claim that the general sentiment within Canada regarding Donald Trump is not particularly... positive. As [CBS News](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/grenier-us-primaries-canada-1.3428524) noted through a poll by [Insights West](http://www.insightswest.com/news/two-thirds-of-canadians-worried-about-trump-victory/), a mere 20 percent of us Canucks believe that Trump would be a good candidate. And, despite his apparent success south of the border, it seems that even his own party doesn't like him anymore. Take a look at what Marco Rubio [said in Florida recently](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ztdzg5kssXk):
> "This is a man who in rallies has told his supporters to basically beat up the people who are in the crowd and he'll pay their legal fees, someone who has encouraged people in the audience to rough up anyone who stands up and says something he doesn't like." <small>- Senator Marco Rubio</small>

Indeed, Trump is encouraging a style of social and political discourse that is not unlike the temper tantrum of a 6 year old - it is an attitude of reckless disregard for the respectful virtues that form the very foundation of modern democracy. So then, you might ask, how is this man getting his votes? The short answer is that he is feeding into the anger of furious, mistreated Americans. The slightly longer answer is that he has created for himself a false facade of "telling it as it is" with his overbearing stature and brutish attitude. Rubio once again comes to the rescue: 

> "This is the intentional injection of the use of people's anger, basically... That is not good leadership, and it is not keeping with our American tradition. That is a style of leadership that says, 'I know you're angry, and I'm going to take advantage of it so that you vote for me.' But what it overlooks is the consequences of it." <small>- Senator Marco Rubio</small>

### A Glimmer of Hope

The good news here is that, despite everything, there is a silver lining. Think of Donald Trump as a fever. Like a fever, he has suddenly and rapidly spread and set fire to large swaths of America. And, like a fever, he will eventually die out and, ultimately, leave America stronger and more immune to the likes of him. In garnering massive media attention through his polarizing statements, Trump has gained vocal opposition from Democrats, Republicans, and now, apparently, [the Communist Party of China](http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/03/china-uses-trump-in-anti-democracy-propaganda.html). He has shown Americans the very hypocrisy that got him famous in the first place - he is quite literally his own archenemy. Now, let's just pray that the host kills the fever and not the other way around. "}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}

In short, he makes the claim that Trump's bigoted, unabashed manner has transcended the line from a political issue to a moral issue. Indeed, never before have I heard anybody, let alone a political figure, say that they "[they] could shoot somebody and not lose any voters." Attribute that and his other statements to simple, pure hyperbole if you will, but there is no denying that Donald Trump has built up a strong, loyal following and, at this point, appears to be the inevitable GOP candidate for the presidency.

As a Canadian citizen, I try not to judge American politics too harshly. With that said, it would be an understatement to claim that the general sentiment within Canada regarding Donald Trump is not particularly... positive. As CBS News noted through a poll by Insights West, a mere 20 percent of us Canucks believe that Trump would be a good candidate. And, despite his apparent success south of the border, it seems that even his own party doesn't like him anymore. Take a look at what Marco Rubio said in Florida recently:

"This is a man who in rallies has told his supporters to basically beat up the people who are in the crowd and he'll pay their legal fees, someone who has encouraged people in the audience to rough up anyone who stands up and says something he doesn't like." - Senator Marco Rubio

Indeed, Trump is encouraging a style of social and political discourse that is not unlike the temper tantrum of a 6 year old - it is an attitude of reckless disregard for the respectful virtues that form the very foundation of modern democracy. So then, you might ask, how is this man getting his votes? The short answer is that he is feeding into the anger of furious, mistreated Americans. The slightly longer answer is that he has created for himself a false facade of "telling it as it is" with his overbearing stature and brutish attitude. Rubio once again comes to the rescue:

"This is the intentional injection of the use of people's anger, basically... That is not good leadership, and it is not keeping with our American tradition. That is a style of leadership that says, 'I know you're angry, and I'm going to take advantage of it so that you vote for me.' But what it overlooks is the consequences of it." - Senator Marco Rubio

A Glimmer of Hope

The good news here is that, despite everything, there is a silver lining. Think of Donald Trump as a fever. Like a fever, he has suddenly and rapidly spread and set fire to large swaths of America. And, like a fever, he will eventually die out and, ultimately, leave America stronger and more immune to the likes of him. In garnering massive media attention through his polarizing statements, Trump has gained vocal opposition from Democrats, Republicans, and now, apparently, the Communist Party of China. He has shown Americans the very hypocrisy that got him famous in the first place - he is quite literally his own archenemy. Now, let's just pray that the host kills the fever and not the other way around.

presidency.

As a Canadian citizen, I try not to judge American politics too harshly. With
that said, it would be an understatement to claim that the general sentiment
within Canada regarding Donald Trump is not particularly... positive. As CBS
News [http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/grenier-us-primaries-canada-1.3428524] 
noted through a poll by Insights West
[http://www.insightswest.com/news/two-thirds-of-canadians-worried-about-trump-victory/]
, a mere 20 percent of us Canucks believe that Trump would be a good candidate.
And, despite his apparent success south of the border, it seems that even his
own party doesn't like him anymore. Take a look at what Marco Rubio said in
Florida recently [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ztdzg5kssXk]:

"This is a man who in rallies has told his supporters to basically beat up the
people who are in the crowd and he'll pay their legal fees, someone who has
encouraged people in the audience to rough up anyone who stands up and says
something he doesn't like." - Senator Marco Rubio

Indeed, Trump is encouraging a style of social and political discourse that is
not unlike the temper tantrum of a 6 year old - it is an attitude of reckless
disregard for the respectful virtues that form the very foundation of modern
democracy. So then, you might ask, how is this man getting his votes? The short
answer is that he is feeding into the anger of furious, mistreated Americans.
The slightly longer answer is that he has created for himself a false facade of
"telling it as it is" with his overbearing stature and brutish attitude. Rubio
once again comes to the rescue:

"This is the intentional injection of the use of people's anger, basically...
That is not good leadership, and it is not keeping with our American tradition.
That is a style of leadership that says, 'I know you're angry, and I'm going to
take advantage of it so that you vote for me.' But what it overlooks is the
consequences of it." - Senator Marco Rubio

A Glimmer of Hope
The good news here is that, despite everything, there is a silver lining. Think
of Donald Trump as a fever. Like a fever, he has suddenly and rapidly spread and
set fire to large swaths of America. And, like a fever, he will eventually die
out and, ultimately, leave America stronger and more immune to the likes of him.
In garnering massive media attention through his polarizing statements, Trump
has gained vocal opposition from Democrats, Republicans, and now, apparently, 
the Communist Party of China
[http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/03/china-uses-trump-in-anti-democracy-propaganda.html]
. He has shown Americans the very hypocrisy that got him famous in the first
place - he is quite literally his own archenemy. Now, let's just pray that the
host kills the fever and not the other way around.

posts.html:
Holy sh*t, it's 10pm and I haven't started on a project that's due tomorrow.

How many times have we all experienced this, how many times have we given ourselves a mental slap in the face? Well, the obvious solution is to not let it happen in the first place (if you're really in dire need, scroll down to damage control)

Prevention

It's really pretty simple... stay on top of everything. How, you ask? Find a way to get organized. Let's face it, unless you're an agenda addict (in which case you wouldn't be reading this), that small booklet is gonna ever work out for you. It's just too time consuming to pull it out every time and try to find the right page. Rather, I personally use electronic notes and calendars. I personally use Google Calendar, but you can use whatever service that seems the easiest to you. In terms of quick notes however (such as your homework and other tasks), nothing beats Google Keep. Why? Google Keep is incredibly easy and fast to use, just type in your note and you're done.

It's incredibly easy to take notes with Google Keep

Damage Control

What if you're in the situation and you're out of options? You're going to have to sacrifice some things.

  1. Calm yourself down, and look at how much time you have.
  2. Look at how many tasks you have left, and rank them by order of importance and time it takes.
  3. Do as many as possible, prioritizing the short and easy tasks and the ones that are the most important first.

Just follow that list and get as much as you can get done, and hope for the best. The key here is organization. Keep a clear head and understand what needs to be done.

Anyways, hope you get your stuff done on time :)

Anyways, hope you get your stuff done on time :)

posts.title: Post-Midtermania: 1st Edition
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":""Why is math so hard?" I hear my friend yell as he stumbles down the stairs, comically bumping into a supporting pole in the process. "Yeah, at least you got the answer", I think. I look down - my freshly-marked midterm looks back up at me condescendingly. 

You know, this post was originally supposed to start off differently. The title used to be, and I quote, "University isn't about friendship or learning. It's about keeping your f**king sanity." But I held off, promising I would come back to it later AFTER I got my midterm results. And, boy, were those midterm results... fun. There were "yes!" moments, "oh no!" moments, and, of course, "this curve makes me a boosted animal" moments. But, above all, there were "I'm glad I didn't go through this alone" moments. 

University/College has been uniquely counterintuitive in this respect. On one hand, you're locking yourself in your room for hours at a time doing math assignments. On the other, you're constantly seeking ways to get out of said room and into the world - the irony of giving up on math homework to play card-based math games (163 anyone??) was never lost of me. Yet, somehow, we all made it through (relatively?) unscathed. **Together**. 

![](https://static.kevinpei.com/2016/12beautiful-1482722735831.jpeg)

Thinking back to high school, I finally understand what my computer engineering teacher meant when he told me the challenges of University would be so much fun. I mean, sure, certain assignments from a certain professor of mine are at least partially responsible for driving me to the edge of insanity at times. But, you know what, I don't blame them. In the end, I, and the rest of my friends, came out smarter, stronger, and better prepared to face the world of... assignments :). 

So as I sit here relishing in my friend's piano playing (and procrastinating a certain assignment from a certain professor), I am struck by just how lucky I and, really, all of us are. Sure, we're passing through hell together. Sure, we're crying together and laughing together and falling asleep doing math together. And, sure, we're probably going insane together. But you know what? We are there for each other - day in and day out. So long as I know that's true, I know we're going to make it through. 

I know it. I really do. 

<3. 

"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}

A cool new parallax effect on the front page, a complete, ES6-friendly rewrite of the JavaScript source, and the long-overdue decision to drop support for IE9. Deployment has also been refined, finally bring with it an automated build process that every developer ever has wanted (but many have not done). I guess, in many ways, this update has been a reflection of my personal growth, a final, hasty rush to cross off the resolutions of yesteryear.

posts.title: Building Seashell: A (more) modern online IDE
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":""Seashell's pretty cool, can I help out with building it?" - those were the words I asked of my Computer Science prof back in my first term of school in the fall of 2016. Before I knew it, emails were sent and niceties were exchanged. It was my first real university side project, and I was ecstatic. Little did I know it would become one of the coolest development projects I've ever participated in. For the uninitiated, Seashell is an online C and Racket development environment used by most first year CS 136 students at the University of Waterloo. It's a mashup of various technologies and systems with the intention of allowing students to write C without having to set up compilers, debuggers, etc. on their local system. Just one problem: it was buggy. About once a week, it would open its nefarious jaws and either crash, refuse to authenticate, or cast the entirety of some poor student's project so deep into oblivion it'd make Hades proud. Clearly, something had gone terribly wrong. ### A classic case of organic growth But what had gone wrong? It was easy to point fingers at the people who developed it, but upon further inspection that didn't make much sense - the codebase was well tested, thoroughly commented, and actively maintained by a team of developers and support staff. So I did what any reasonable developer would do; I asked the existing team. The answer was simple: ![The Old Seashell Interface](https://static.kevinpei.com/2017/03Screen_Shot_2017_03_17_at_4_16_30_PM-1489781805066.png)

The old Seashell interface

Indeed, from a technical perspective, Seashell is actually quite a feat - integrating service workers and [a port of Clang to JavaScript](https://github.com/cs136/seashell-clang-js) to allow students to compile their code even when completely offline. And, for all its flaws, it's certainly done its job - relieving professors from the arduous task of getting hundreds of undergraduate students to setup MinGW/GNU GCC/Clang/Visual C++ on their system reliably. - Ask around, get involved! "}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
"Seashell's pretty cool, can I help out with building it?" - those were the words I asked of my Computer Science prof back in my first term of school in the fall of 2016. Before I knew it, emails were sent and niceties were exchanged. It was my first real university side project, and I was ecstatic. Little did I know it would become one of the coolest development projects I've ever participated in.

For the uninitiated, Seashell is an online C and Racket development environment used by most first year CS 136 students at the University of Waterloo. It's a mashup of various technologies and systems with the intention of allowing students to write C without having to set up compilers, debuggers, etc. on their local system.

Just one problem: it was buggy. About once a week, it would open its nefarious jaws and either crash, refuse to authenticate, or cast the entirety of some poor student's project so deep into oblivion it'd make Hades proud. Clearly, something had gone terribly wrong.

A classic case of organic growth

But what had gone wrong? It was easy to point fingers at the people who developed it, but upon further inspection that didn't make much sense - the codebase was well tested, thoroughly commented, and actively maintained by a team of developers and support staff. So I did what any reasonable developer would do; I asked the existing team. The answer was simple:

The old Seashell interface

Indeed, from a technical perspective, Seashell is actually quite a feat - integrating service workers and a port of Clang to JavaScript to allow students to compile their code even when completely offline. And, for all its flaws, it's certainly done its job - relieving professors from the arduous task of getting hundreds of undergraduate students to setup MinGW/GNU GCC/Clang/Visual C++ on their system reliably.

  • Ask around, get involved!
